subtitleNullable: Cannabis is legal in Connecticut since 2021. Did usage explode?
descriptionNullable:
# Cannabis in Connecticut

Cannabis in Connecticut is legal for recreational use since July 1, 2021; while medical use was legalized through legislation passed in 2012.

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-user-content/o/inbox%2F6808204%2Ffb4b7806548f16142065ccbe7694b45e%2F360_F_224186701_lSwI6MAmSugPtITPJ8hxKb7IqI0bBdFn.jpg?generation=1716197031557583&alt=media)


# What are the consequences of legalization of marijuana:

1) price collapse: [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/09/05/how-legalization-caused-the-price-of-marijuana-to-collapse/)

2) junk food sales increase [University of Connecticut](https://today.uconn.edu/2019/02/uconn-study-junk-food-purchases-increase-recreational-marijuana-legalization/)

3) very little evidence that it negatively effect labor market outcomes [National Bureau of Economic Research](https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w30813/w30813.pdf)


# Dataset

This data set contains preliminary weekly retail sales data for cannabis and cannabis products in both the adult-use cannabis and medical marijuana markets in Connecticut (CT), U.S. 

The weekly data set captures retail cannabis sales from Sunday through Saturday of the week. Weeks spanning across two different months only include days within the same month. The first and last week of each month may show lower sales as they may not be made up of a full week (7 days). Data values may be updated and change over time as updates occur. Accordingly, weekly reported data may not exactly match annually reported data.


(image credit: Washington Post)
title: Cannabis Retail Sales Weekly (CT)
subtitle: Cannabis is legal in Connecticut since 2021. Did usage explode?
description:
# Cannabis in Connecticut

Cannabis in Connecticut is legal for recreational use since July 1, 2021; while medical use was legalized through legislation passed in 2012.

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-user-content/o/inbox%2F6808204%2Ffb4b7806548f16142065ccbe7694b45e%2F360_F_224186701_lSwI6MAmSugPtITPJ8hxKb7IqI0bBdFn.jpg?generation=1716197031557583&alt=media)


# What are the consequences of legalization of marijuana:

1) price collapse: [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/09/05/how-legalization-caused-the-price-of-marijuana-to-collapse/)

2) junk food sales increase [University of Connecticut](https://today.uconn.edu/2019/02/uconn-study-junk-food-purchases-increase-recreational-marijuana-legalization/)

3) very little evidence that it negatively effect labor market outcomes [National Bureau of Economic Research](https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w30813/w30813.pdf)


# Dataset

This data set contains preliminary weekly retail sales data for cannabis and cannabis products in both the adult-use cannabis and medical marijuana markets in Connecticut (CT), U.S. 

The weekly data set captures retail cannabis sales from Sunday through Saturday of the week. Weeks spanning across two different months only include days within the same month. The first and last week of each month may show lower sales as they may not be made up of a full week (7 days). Data values may be updated and change over time as updates occur. Accordingly, weekly reported data may not exactly match annually reported data.


(image credit: Washington Post)
